essay.question-text: Some people prefer to study a little in many subjects, while others would prefer to study a single subject in depth. Which do you prefer, and why? Use specific details and examples to support your response.
essay.sample-answer-text:
SAMPLE ANSWER
At my university I studied engineering, and almost nothing but engineering. All the classes I took were in some way related to my major. I didn't have any art, or history, or things like that. If I had been given the choice, I would've preferred to learn a little about many subjects instead of so much about my major.
If I have a conversation with other engineers, I feel pretty knowledgeable about just about anything in my field. I'm really good at what I do, and that's great for my job. But when it comes to life, I don't feel prepared, and I think my school could've done a better job. What happens if I meet someone and want to discuss literature? Too bad, I can't. I have no idea about it. Or art. Or lots of other things.
I think the best option would be to have a combination between studying a subject or major in depth and also taking other classes outside of my major to be more well-balanced as a person. I'm interested in other subjects, but because I could study only engineering, I didn't get to learn about them. I think a student needs balance between the two.
